msIdentifier.repository: National Archives and Records Administration, Seattle Branch, Washington
msIdentifier.collection: RG 21: US District Court, Western Division of Washington, Seatle

div1.p: Exhibit "C" Statement of K. Umeda, Made at Oakland Cal. June 2, 1913
K. Umeda sworn by Thos M. Fisher

My first connection with this case was when I lived upstairs over Ito's place at 1020 Stockton St., San Francisco. There was trouble there, the girl, Hana, wanted to live with Saito and I was appealed to be Washio to held settle the trouble, I refused at first but later Saito came to me and I said I would help. Saito said he wanted to go into the country for the purpose of raising this money. They money mentioned was money that it was agreed Saito was to pay Washio for the girl Hana, I don;t recall the exact amount. Saito asked me to stand good for the money also to stand good for come bills he owed at some stores. I guaranted that Saito would pay the money and on the strength of that guarantee Washio and Ito allowed Hana to go with Saito. Ito was running a house of prostitution at 1020 Stockton St., Saito and Hana were to go to Sacramento and possibly Fresno the understanding being that they were to return in two weeks, they to try to raise the money in that time. Instead of returning as agreed they ran away and went up north.

What I did in this matter in the first place was done through friendship for Saito. When they didn't come back they all came to me,. I having stook good for Saito, I had nbo interest whatsoever in the woman or her earnings other then as I have already told you. Washio sentphotographs of Hana around the country to try to locate them, Washio was sore at e and also all the places where Saito owed money. Having gone good for these people I paid a number of the bills they owed then I went to Seattle to try to locate them, when I arrived at Seattle I was met by a Japanese, whose name I don't know, who had a telegram from Washio which he showed me saying I was going to Seattle, that was soemtime in June or July 1912. I didn't locate them so I came back to San Francisco, I was looking for them about a week where she was, but when he started to show me he didn't know where she was or couldn't find her and then he said she must have gone to Tacoma. I went to Tacoma but couldn't find her. Washio was in San Francisco when I returned. While I was in Seattle this Japanese brought a man to my room and said he was a detective who had been trying to locate Hana. I was rooming in the Ujine Hotel.

Shortly after I returned to San Francisco Washio went to Seattle he wired to Ito from Seattle telling him to go to the Burns Agency and Ito and I and Nakada went there. Washio had written a letter to Ito telling Ito to have me swear out a warrant for Hana, when we asked the Burns people about that they said it couldn't be done. Ito got some other wires from Washio later and told me the party was coming. I didn('t go to the boat to meet them but I believe Ito did, also his wife. The next night after they arrived I had a fight with Saito and I hit him with a baibard cue, right after the fight I went up to Ito's house of prostitution at 1020 Stockton St., Young and Sugiura were present when Saito and I had the fight and they went up to Ito's with me, after we got up in Ito's place Young and Siguria said that Washio had agreed to pay them $800. for bringing Hana back and that they wanted their money. I turned to Washio and asked him how he could make that kind of an agreement when he didn(t have any money. 15
Young and Sugiura told Ito and I that as Washio didn't have any money we would have to pay them. We told them that as Washio had made the agreement with them they must look to him for theirmoney, the next day we went to the Imperial hotel on Ene St,m where Young and Sugiura were staying, to see them, Washio and I went there together and we met Saito near there and went in the hotel all together, Young and Sugiura were both there, they said they had made an agreement with Washio to bring the girl back to San Francisco and that he was to pay them as soon as they arrived but he had gone gone back on his agreement, we didn't arrve at any settlement that day but that evening Young and Sugiura came to Ito's house and they called for me to come theretoo, we talked about a settlement. Ito finally agreed to pay part of the money and they he asked me to loan him some as he didn't have enough, I didn't have any ready money but I let Ito have my watch which he took out and pawned it, he camed back and handed me $200. in gold which I threw on the table Sugiura picked it up and counted it and handed it to Young who put it in his pocket, Ito told me he paid them $50. more later.

Young and Sugiura told us they had a lot of trouble getting the woman and that they had to make her believe they were Immigration officers, they said they were not taking chances on bringing her down there to a house of prostitution for nothing and that it was worth $800. to take the chances they had taken. They said that they knew she was comming here to go into a house of prostitution and that she was to do business here as a prostitute.

When we first got a tip that there was trouble started over this woman haveing been brought down here Nakada phoned to Ito and I to come to his office and when we went there he told us to get Hana out of that house and hide her away he said the officers would be around after that night or the next day. The next day Nakada came to Ito's house with an officer looking for her. I asked Nakada what they wanted and he said we want the woman and that we must give her up. I then went with Nakada and the officer to the room where Hana was I asked Nakada what it ment and he said it was Seattle case and that if I would give $40. he would fix things with the United States Marshal so I wouldn't get into any trouble. Ito came to me the next day and showed me $20. and two $10. in gold and said he was taking it to Nakada for fixing things for him and wanted me to go with him and the money he came with an officer and arrested Ito's wife, I went to Nakada then and asked him if they wanted me too he said he had fixed things all right, he had told me before that to hide out as I was wanted.
It was the understanding of all of us that if found Hana was to be brought back to Ito's house of prostitution.
I certify the foregoing is a true and full transcript of the stenographic notes made by me at the time of statement.
